Planning to pressurise

Otherwise 4
0...Rxh2 is +mate! But now if I play 40...Rxh2, White plays 41.Kg5 and the
position now looks extremely promising for White, so...

White's last card, he opens up the position around the Black King in order to
be able to do some damage with his Queen, winning a few pawns, hoping for a
blunder with a route to mate or failing that a perpetual check.

I considered c2 & d2 the best squares for
my 2 Rooks, preventing the White Queen from having access to the c-file and

Qa3 Bxd4 18. Bxd4 Qxd4+ 19. Kh1 Nc6 20. Rad1 Qb6 21. Qb3 Nd4 22. Qb2 Rfd8 23. e5 Rac8 24. Rd2 Qc5 25. Rfd1 Nc6 26. f4 Qe3 27. g3 Qf3+ 28. Kg1 Nd4 29. Bf1 Qxd1 30. Rxd1 Nf3+ 31. Kf2 Rxd1 32. Kxf3 Rxf1+ 33. Kg2 Rd1 34. Kh3 Kf7 35. Qe2 Rcd8 36. Qb2 R8d2 37. Qa3 h5 38. Qf3 Ra1 39. Qe4 Raxa2 40. Kh4 Re2 41. Qd3 Rad2 42. Qb1 Rxh2+ 43. Kg5 Rc2 44. Kh6 h4 45. g4 h3 46. f5 gxf5 47. gxf5 exf5 48. Qb3+ e6 49. Qe3 Rhd2 50. Qg5 h2 51. Qf6+ Ke8 52. Qxe6+ Kd8 53. Qb6+ Kd7 54. e6+ Ke7 55. Qb7+ Kxe6 56. Qxa6+ Rd6 57. Qa1 b4 58. Qb1 Rg2 59. Kh5 Rd8 60. Qe1+ Kf7
comment:
It's mate in 3. White cannot prevent both ...Rh8+ and h1=R+. He can
only stop one of those moves from mating (if for example he plays 61.Qa1)
thereafter the other move will give mate. 61.Qg3 Rxg3 62.Kh4 Rdg8 63.Kh5 and I
have a choice between  h1=R+mate and Rh3+mate and Rh8+mate. Alternatively he
could play 61.Qe6 7 or 8 check, but this only prolongs the game for one more
move and it's still mate on the next move, hence Graham's resignation.
